History:
Long-term climate observations are rather expensive and therefore the number of climate
stations is limited. Moreover, the spatial representativeness of the stations is often restricted
to the close vicinity of the stations. Nevertheless, it is desirable to have area covering climate
information in a whole region. Upscaling, i.e. the transformation of the local climate
information of a station to its greater environment is not always possible in complex terrain.
However, the climate on the large scale is often well known since there are many climate
stations in an area of continental dimension. This opens the opportunity of downscaling, i.e.
the transformation of large-scale climate informations to smaller-scale regions. The
downscaling method, of course, must consider the specific topographical effects on the
climate in the region of interest. Climate observations of a future climate do of course not
exist. Only large-scale model simulations (GCM simulation) are available. In this case
downscaling is the only way to attain regional climate or climate-change informations.
Since the late seventies numerical mesoscale models are available. Given a large-scale
meteorological situations and the regional topography these models are capable of calculating
the corresponding mesoscale distribution of meteorological parameters. Since the early
eighties mesoscale models are used for statistical-dynamical downscaling, i.e. given a
large-scale climate and the regional topography these models calculate the corresponding
mesoscale distribution of climatological parameters.
Early applications aimed at the wind climatology (e.g. wind roses) in rather small areas. The
first 'downscaled' wind rose was published by Wippermann and Gross (1981). An extended
rose-bed, i.e. a two-dimensional array of synthetic wind roses, was published by Heimann
(1986). Later applications followed, among them assessments of the regional wind-power
availability.
